overview_of_class:
Acts of persuasion affect us in all aspects of our lives. This course will examine the different ways in which we observe and use persuasion in the communication we have with our families, our friends, and the general public. How effective are we? How are we affected by persuasion? This will culminate in an overall assessment of persuasion's effects on us as individuals and as a society.

This hybrid course combines in-class lecture and discussion on campus with online sessions. In-class meeting dates are 3/29, 4/5, 4/19, 5/3, 5/17, and 5/31. Attendance at the first session is mandatory; attendance is required for all subsequent sessions. Absences for both in-class meetings and online sessions will affect the final grade. Homework will be due in class and online.
name: Theories of Persuasion

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Understand and apply the large variety of persuasion theories.
Utilize the terminology used in the field, including some theorists' names.
Analyze and evaluate yourself and others-as a persuader and a persuadee.
Improve your own communication, using the theories and practical knowledge learned in class.
